Along similar lines, a higher inflation target allows property prices to fall quite quickly in real terms without causing bank collateral to be lost, which is what happens when property prices have to fall in nominal terms so crushing the banking system.

Another advantage I'm surprised you don't mention (since you have before) is that a higher inflation target would make internal revaluation easier to do.

Even America, with its fiscal transfers and fairly mobile labor markets, might be able to benefit from this effect - since regional competiveness issues are not unheard of here.

This is why education should be free or very low cost.  Society benefits by having people with a broad understanding of all aspects of educational life. When I went to a UC school in 1965 my memory is that student fees (there was no tuition) totalled about $275 a year, even at at 10x inflation factor, that would be $2750 a year.  What are UC campuses now, maybe $12,000?

How does he propose a teacher be measured on their ability to make students excited about stuff? If not measured by more objective criteria, it's a ready formula for allowing both teachers and students to not really do what they need to be doing: teachers teaching, students learning.

Every now and then, someone in the education field suggests that teaching should not be so much about learning as it ought to be about how everyone *feels*: "intellectually enriched", etc. This is the ideal approach to take to produce a lot of unemployable people with high loan debt but who feel good about themselves anyway. Waxing philosophic about Plato may make you feel "enlightened" but that and $5 will get you a latte at Starbucks. Given that most people have one shot at college and that it's usually a very expensive one, there's no room for error. If plunking down $150k for a college degree, it better be measurably worth it to you. A student has the rest of his/her life to learn abt. Hobbes or Wittgenstein, esp. as the source materials and pretty much all the typical textbooks are available on-line. The real world demands practical prioritization. This means making sensible and practical decisions abt. how to spend scarce dollars. A degree in Philosophy, etc., is great, but the demand for such grads is very low. Young people today can't afford to major in just anything. It has to have a payoff or it's a long, painful journey of albatross-like debt around the neck for decades.

Have they not been paying attention? Fortunately, the President has shown that he has the wisdom and character to persevere when all around him are willing to accuse him of every kind of failure. The military responds to commands. Dubya forgot to order them to win in Iraq, and that is why they didnt. Or maybe the military was ordered to avoid any developments that would make dubya's reelection more difficult (such as being honest about the course of the war). They were pretty good at that.

Releasing Gitmo prisoners in a way that Congress prohibited would be an impeachable offense. Supporting secular moderates would risk support mistakenly or accidentally going to Islamists, which would again be grounds for impeachment.

You want Obama to do something that would perhaps have more wings than Benghazi so his opponents would have a better shot at impeaching him (or at least making sure that his main accomplishment was avoiding getting removed from office).

You illustrate a much broader problem than an inability to shut down Gitmo; and that problem is detachment, a disengagement from the requirements of command and of simple effective management. He doesn't confront, he doesn't challenge, he doesn't set objectives and he doesn't keep on top of those charged with securing them. Any obstacle becomes insurmountable, or requiring of more energy and attention than it's worth to overcome.

An effective executive states unequivocally what he wants to accomplish, charges people to go figure out how to do it, then supervises the execution to make sure it actually happens. He doesn't do any of that.

He doesn't tell State and CIA that he wishes to be sure that as Arab Spring builds that secular moderates are supported so that they have an even playing field against Islamists to secure electoral power; nor does he ask his people why this isn't happening as Islamists secure reinforced footholds.

He doesn't tell the military to figure out a way to close Gitmo that doesn't require releasing into the ether real terrorists but immediately releases the "low value" prisoners -- the military responds to commands; so, command them, and soon enough they'll come up with options. No, when Congress protests, he caves ... and let's the problem fester.

Once old format files are digitized, what are the best resources for helping people to share, sort, and save the newly-created digital files?

Thanks for answering these questions!
I use www.Carbonite.com, a Mass. company for an annual fee of $59 to date.

Last year I archived several hundred 19th century family photos as TIFFs using Adobe Elements and Adobe's cloud storage. Adobe recently announced that they are moving to a new storage platform which will only support jpegs, so all TIFFS must be downloaded by June 18 or disappear. More than 24 hours of downloading so far and still not done! But it raises the question: if your master archive is kept as a jpeg, but all editing work is done on a copy, is a non-jpeg format for archiving really that important?

I only used one external hard drive, for backup.  Drop it once, and it's history itself.  Although USB thumb drives do fail, the ones I use seem very reliable.  I make multiple copies of anything important.

What is the role of metadata in the personal/ family archive. Should independent archivist have a metadata strategy when preserving digital historical material? Where do we even begin?!

I would also love to hear your thoughts on the longevity of external hard drives.

I thought about that as well -- that one doesn't typically think of couples who constantly bicker as being wholly and completely in love. I grew up in a polite household and when I was around bickering families it made me very, very nervous. Yet, when you think of it, what is love if not being totally and completely yourself and that means (for opinionated people especially) being able to bicker and argue and still be deeply in love. Much better than being polite and tiptoeing around each other for fear of offending. That's not authentic. Plus, Mr. MacSwain grew up in a tightknit household that bickered constantly and loved each other ferociously. He likely mellowed a bit, and she likely learned to bicker a bit. Works for them! Love it.

The "bickering...absolutely constant" would probably not be everyone's idea of the key ingredient for a long, successful relationship, but it seems to work for Tracy and Grant. The strong bonds they have formed in other areas seem to balance things out in the long run.

It just shows to go ya', even the most improbable souls can make the most wonderful soulmates. Congratulations and best wishes to each of them or a continued long, happy marriage.

Seems like the target is a price support scheme. Central banks use monetary restraint to hold inflation and interest rates to a pattern deemed desirable. E.g., they might aim for the 3% 10-year natural rate plus 2 points for inflation leading to a 5% rate on 10-Year Treasuries. I.E., bankers relate to the central banks the same way farmers once related to the Department of Agriculture's price supports for agricultural commodities. Like farmers the bankers claim to deal with risk and uncertainty that would paralyze ordinary mortals in fear. Like the DOA, central banks dutifully do all that they can to make banks profitable and eliminate that risk and uncertainty.

There is a complication. Farmers only needed DOA to control one economic variable per market. The central banks however are asked to systematically influence two economic variables--interest rates and inflation rates--a two-genie-one-bottle problem. Hence, the bankers see the potential for something to slip out of control. Thus, they demand extremely low inflation rates to give themselves a deep buffer against spiking interest rates.

The central banks know that they need to pay lip service to various economic variables that weigh on the common good, but they are bankers who know that they must take care of bankers. They seem to believe that the world's fortunes must compromised in order to hold inflation to 2%. No one but bankers cares otherwise and most of us want 4% and could be happy at 6%.
